case_name: Petitioners v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 327 of 1968 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for habeas corpus

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 327 of 1968. Petition under Art 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioners obtained rule against State of West Bengal to show cause why writ of habeas corpus should not be issued

anchor.surface_text: In this case the petitioners have obtained a rule upon the respondent, viz., the State of West Bengal, to show cause why a writ of habeas companypus should number be issued under Art. 32 of the Constitution directing their release from detention under orders passed under s. 3 2  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950  Act, IV of 1950   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Hearing of petition concluded on 15th January 1969 and court directed release of petitioners

anchor.surface_text: At the companyclusion of the hearing of this petition on 15th January, 1969, we directed the release of these petitioners and said that the reasons would be furnished later.

facts.text: Detention order against Sk. Abdul Karim (petitioner No. 2) made on 17th February 1968 by District Magistrate of Hooghly

anchor.surface_text: As regards petitioner No. 2 Sk. Abdul Karim, the order of detention was made on 17th February, 1968 by the District Magistrate of Hooghly and reads as follows No. 230-C Dated 17-2-1968 Whereas I am satisfied with respect to the person known as Sk. Abdul Karim, son of late Sk. Nasiruddin of Mathurdangi, Police-station Chanditala District Hooghly,

facts.text: Sk. Abdul Karim arrested on 2-2-68 at 19.05 hours carrying 60 kgs of rice without authority from Dankuni Bazar towards Dankuni Rly Station

anchor.surface_text: on the following grounds That on 2-2-68, at 19.05, hours you were arrested while carrying 60 kgs. of rice without authority from Dankuni Bazar towards Dankuni Rly. Station with a view to despatch the same by train into the statutory rationing areas of Calcutta and Howrah.

facts.text: Sk. Abdul Karim found detraining at Dankuni Rly Station on 9-2-68 at 14.00 hrs with one maund of rice

anchor.surface_text: That on 9-2-68 at 14.00 hrs. you were found to detrain at Dankuni Rly. Station with a bag companytaining one maund of rice from Burdwan-Howrah local train.

facts.text: Sk. Abdul Karim with 2/3 other smugglers carrying 20 kgs rice each by train from Dankuni to Sealdah, detrained at Baranagore on 10-2-68 at 13.55 hrs

anchor.surface_text: That on 10-2-68 at 13.55 hrs. you with 2/3 other smugglers were found to carry rice 20 kgs. each, by train from Dankuni Rly. Station towards Sealdah and you all detrained at Baranagore off side platform with unauthorised stocks of rice.

facts.text: Sk. Abdul Karim with other smugglers carrying 15 kgs rice each by train towards Howrah from Dankuni on 11-2-68 at 08.45 hrs

anchor.surface_text: That on 11-2-68 at 08,45 hrs. you with other smugglers were found carrying 15 kgs. of rice each by train towards Howrah from Dankuni Rly. Station.

facts.text: Sk. Abdul Karim made representation to State Government on 21st February 1968 against detention order

anchor.surface_text: On 21st February, 1968, Sk. Abdul Karim made a representation, to the State Government against the order of detention.

facts.text: Advisory Board made report on 22nd April 1968 stating sufficient cause for detention of Sk. Abdul Karim

anchor.surface_text: On 22nd April, 1968, the Advisory Board made a report under section 10 of the Act stating that there was sufficient cause for detention of Sk. Abdul Karim.

facts.text: Governor of West Bengal confirmed detention order on 24th July 1968 under section 11(1)

anchor.surface_text: On 24th July, 1968, the Governor of West Bengal companyfirmed the detention order under section 11  1  of the Act.

facts.text: Petitioners argued that their representations were not considered by respondent Government before forwarding to Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by Mr. Garg that the representations of the petitioners were number companysidered by the respondent Government of West Bengal, but were merely forwarded by the respondent to the Advisory Board without any companysideration.

facts.text: In first counter-affidavit, respondent asserted no requirement for State Government to consider representation before forwarding to Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: In the first companynter-affidavit of the respondent it was asserted by Mr. Monoranjan Dey that there was numberrequirement of law which companypelled the companysideration by the State Government of the detenus representation before being forwarded to the Advisory Board for companysideration.

facts.text: In second counter-affidavit, respondent stated Government refrained from expressing views to secure unprejudiced consideration by Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: In the second companynteraffidavit Mr. Monoranjan Dey said that for securing an unprejudiced and impartial companysideration of the representation of the petitioner by an independent Statutory Authority, the State Government refrained at that stage from expressing its views on-the representations to the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Counter-affidavits of respondents are vague and allegation of petitioner not categorically denied

anchor.surface_text: The companynter- affidavits of the respondents are some what vague and the allegation of the petitioner has number been categorically denied.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent said case may be decided on footing that representations were not considered by State Government before sending to Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Debabrata Mukherjee, however, said in the companyrse of argument that the case may be decided on the footing that the representations were number companysidered by the State Government before sending them to the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Court held that State Government failed to consider representation of Sk. Abdul Karim before forwarding to Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, Sk. Abdul Karim has alleged that his representation was number companysidered by the State Government before it was forwarded to the Advisory Board. This allegation is number companytroverted in the companynter-affidavit filed on behalf of the respondent.

facts.text: Court held detention order dated 17-2-1968 against Sk. Abdul Karim illegal and ultra vires due to failure to consider representation

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the order of detention dated 17-2-1968 made against petitioner No. 2, Sk. Abdul Karim and the subsequent order of the Governor of West Bengal dated 24th April, 1968 companyfirming the order of detention must be held to be illegal and ultra vires

facts.text: Detention orders against petitioners Nos. 5 Nirmal Chandra Jana, 6 Sk. Ibrahim and 8 Nur Mohd suffer from same defect

anchor.surface_text: In the case of petitioners Nos. 5, Nirmal Chandra Jana, No. 6 Sk. Ibrahim and No. 8 Nur Mohd. the order of detention suffers from the same legal defect as the order of detention in the case of petitioner No. 2, Sk. Abdul Karim.

facts.text: Court held orders of detention and confirmation for petitioners Nos. 5,6,8 illegal and ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already stated we hold that the order of detention and the order of companyfirmation under section 11 of the Act in the case of petitioners Nos. 5, 6 and 8 were also illegal and ultra vires and the petitioners were companysequently entitled to be released.

On 24th July, 1968, the Governor of West Bengal companyfirmed the detention order under section 11  1  of the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Government confirms detention if Advisory Board finds sufficient cause.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: companysider the representation and to take appropriate action thereon. Otherwise the right of representation companyferred by Art. 22 5  of the Const

anchor.surface_text: Section 11A states 11A.  1  The maximum period for which any person may be detained in pursuance of any detention order which has been companyfirmed under section 1 1 shall be twelve months
Section 13 provides for revocation of a detention order and reads as follows - 13.  1   Without prejudice to the provisions of section 21 of the General Clauses Act, 1897

concepts.interpretation: Power to revoke detention order at any time.

anchor.surface_text: the detention infringes the fundamental right of the detenu guaranteed under Articles 21 and 22 of the Constitution.

concepts.interpretation: Procedural safeguards protect right to life and liberty.

anchor.surface_text: Article 22  4 ,  5 ,  6  and  7  provides as follows 22. No law providing for Preventive detention shall authorise the detention of a person for a longer period than three months, unless-  a an Advisory Board

concepts.unlisted_description: Advisory Board requirement for detention over 3 months

anchor.surface_text: When any person is detained in pursuance of an order made under any law providing for preventive detention, the authority making the order shall, as soon as may be, companymunicate to such person the grounds on which the order has been made and shall afford him the earliest opportunity of making a representation against the order.

concepts.interpretation: Implicitly requires the State Government to properly consider the representation expeditiously, independently of Advisory Board; failure renders detention illegal.
concepts.unlisted_description: Right to grounds and representation in preventive detention

anchor.surface_text: Parliament may by law prescribe-  a  the circumstances under which, and the class or classes of cases in which, a per-son may be detained for a period longer than three months under any law providing for preventive detention without obtaining the opinion of the Advisory Board

concepts.interpretation: Parliament's power to prescribe procedure without Advisory Board in certain cases, but right to representation persists.
concepts.unlisted_description: Parliament's legislative power on preventive detention

anchor.surface_text: The question involved in this case depends upon the companystruction of Art. 22 5  of the Constitution which has already been reproduced.

concepts.interpretation: Prescribes minimum procedure for preventive detention laws; non-compliance infringes fundamental rights.

All the procedural requirements of Article 22 are in our opinion mandatory in character and even if one of the procedural requirement is number companyplied with, the order of detention would be rendered illegal.

concepts.interpretation: Procedural safeguards in Art.22 are mandatory.

issues.text: Whether a writ of habeas corpus should be issued under Art. 32 of the Constitution directing release from detention under orders passed under s. 3(2) of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: why a writ of habeas companypus should number be issued under Art. 32 of the Constitution directing their release from detention under orders passed under s. 3 2  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950

issues.text: Whether the State Government is under a legal obligation to consider the detenu's representation before forwarding it to the Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by Mr. Garg that the representations of the petitioners were number companysidered by the respondent Government of West Bengal, but were merely forwarded by the respondent to the Advisory Board without any companysideration. It was companytended that the detention of the petitioners was bad in law, because there,was a failure on the part of the Government to companysider the representations submitted by the petitioners before forwarding them to the Advisory Board. [...] The question involved in this case depends upon the companystruction of Art. 22 5  of the Constitution

issues.text: Whether non-compliance with procedural requirements of Article 22 renders the detention order illegal

anchor.surface_text: All the procedural requirements of Article 22 are in our opinion mandatory in character and even if one of the procedural requirement is number companyplied with, the order of detention would be rendered illegal.

arguments.claim: Representations of petitioners were not considered by respondent Government but merely forwarded to Advisory Board without consideration

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by Mr. Garg that the representations of the petitioners were not considered by the respondent Government of West Bengal, but were merely forwarded by the respondent to the Advisory Board without any consideration.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that the detention of the petitioners was bad in law, because there was a failure on the part of the Government to consider the representations submitted by the petitioners before forwarding them to the Advisory Board.

arguments.claim: No requirement of law compelling State Government to consider detenu's representation before forwarding to Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: In the first counter-affidavit of the respondent it was asserted by Mr. Monoranjan Dey that there was no requirement of law which compelled the consideration by the State Government of the detenus representation before being forwarded to the Advisory Board for consideration.

arguments.court_reasoning: Implicit in Art.22(5) that govt must consider expeditiously

arguments.claim: State Government refrained from expressing views on representations to secure unprejudiced consideration by Advisory Board

arguments.claim: Case may be decided on footing that representations were not considered by State Government before sending to Advisory Board

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Debabrata Mukherjee, however, said in the course of argument that the case may be decided on the footing that the representations were not considered by the State Government before sending them to the Advisory Board.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to companysider the representation of the detenu before such a reference is made. In the present case, Sk. Abdul Karim has alleged that his representa

arguments.claim: No obligation on State Government to consider representations since Advisory Board constituted to consider case of detenus

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the respondent that there was no obligation on the State Government to consider the repre- sentations since the Advisory Board had been constituted under section 8 of the Act to consider the case of the detenus and to report to the State Government whether there was sufficient cause for their detention.

arguments.court_reasoning: Constitution of AB does not relieve govt of obligation under Art.22(5)

arguments.claim: Art.22(5) implicitly requires State Government to consider representation expeditiously and independently of Advisory Board
Constitution of Advisory Board does not relieve State Government from legal obligation to consider detenu's representation upon receipt
Constitutional right to representation under Art.22(5) includes right to proper consideration by authority to whom made
Right of representation under Art.22(5) is valuable constitutional right, not mere formality; cannot keep in cold storage till AB
Example: In mistaken identity case, govt must consider representation promptly using s.13 power, not wait for AB

anchor.surface_text: Take for instance a case of detention of a person on account of mistaken identity. If the order of detention has been made against A and a different person B is arrested and detained by the police authorities because of similarity of names or some such cause, it cannot be reasonably said that the State Government should wait for the report of the Advisory Board before releasing the wrong person from detention.

arguments.claim: Obligation to consider representation exists even without AB (under Art.22(4),(7)), no dichotomy between cases
Even if reference to AB under s.9, govt obliged to consider representation before reference
Procedural requirements of Art.22 mandatory; non-compliance renders detention illegal and ultra vires
Detention orders against petitioner No.2 Sk. Abdul Karim and confirmation illegal due to failure to consider representation

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the order of detention dated 17-2-1968 made against petitioner No. 2, Sk. Abdul Karim and the subsequent order of the Governor of West Bengal dated 24th April, 1968 confirming the order of detention must be held to be illegal and ultra vires

arguments.claim: Detention orders against petitioners Nos.5,6,8 suffer same defect as No.2, hence illegal

anchor.surface_text: In the case of petitioners Nos. 5, Nirmal Chandra Jana, No. 6 Sk. Ibrahim and No. 8 Nur Mohd. the order of detention suffers from the same legal defect as the order of detention in the case of petitioner No. 2, Sk. Abdul Karim.

holdings.text: It is necessarily implicit in the language of Art.22(5) that the State Government to whom the representation is made should properly consider the representation as expeditiously as possible.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual implication from Art.22(5) requiring expeditious consideration by government independent of Advisory Board

holdings.text: The constitution of an Advisory Board under section 8 of the Act does not relieve the State Government from the legal obligation to consider the representation of the detenu as soon as it is received by it.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Act and Constitution; obligation persists despite Advisory Board

holdings.text: The constitutional right to make a representation guaranteed by Art. 22(5) must be taken to include by necessary implication the constitutional right to a proper consideration of the representation by the authority to whom it is made.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary implication from constitutional right to representation includes proper consideration

holdings.text: All the procedural requirements of Article 22 are in our opinion mandatory in character and even if one of the procedural requirement is not complied with, the order of detention would be rendered illegal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural safeguards in Art.22 mandatory to protect personal liberty

holdings.text: The order of detention dated 17-2-1968 made against petitioner No. 2, Sk. Abdul Karim and the subsequent order of the Governor of West Bengal dated 24th July, 1968 confirming the order of detention must be held to be illegal and ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the order of detention dated 17-2-1968 made against petitioner No. 2, Sk. Abdul Karim and the subsequent order of the Governor of West Bengal dated 24th July, 1968 confirming the order of detention must be held to be illegal and ultra vires and petitioner No. 2 Sk, Abdul Karim was entitled to be released.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failure to consider representation violates Art.22(5); allegation not controverted

holdings.text: In the case of petitioners Nos. 5, Nirmal Chandra Jana, No. 6 Sk. Ibrahim and No. 8 Nur Mohd. the order of detention suffers from the same legal defect as the order of detention in the case of petitioner No. 2, Sk. Abdul Karim.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of petitioners Nos. 5, Nirmal Chandra Jana, No. 6 Sk. Ibrahim and No. 8 Nur Mohd. the order of detention suffers from the same legal defect as the order of detention in the case of petitioner No. 2, Sk. Abdul Karim. For the reasons already stated we hold that the order of detention and the order of confirmation under section 11 of the Act in the case of petitioners Nos. 5, 6 and 8 were also illegal and ultra vires

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same failure to consider representations applies by analogy

holdings.text: Even if reference is to be made to the Advisory Board under section 9 of the Act, the appropriate Government is under legal obligation to consider the representation of the detenu before such a reference is made.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Obligation precedes reference to Board; no dichotomy in Art.22(5)

anchor.surface_text: At the conclusion of the hearing of this petition on 15th January, 1969, we directed the release of these petitioners and said that the reasons would be furnished later.

outcome.relief_summary: Court directed the release of the petitioners as the detention orders were held illegal and ultra vires due to failure to consider representations before referring to Advisory Board.

Ibrahim and No. 8 Nur Mohd. the order of detention suffers from the same legal defect as the order of detention in the case of petitioner No. 2, Sk. Abdul Karim. For the reasons already stated we hold that the order of detention and the order of confirmation under section 11 of the Act in the case of petitioners Nos. 5, 6 and 8 were also illegal and ultra vires
At the conclusion of the hearing of this petition on 15th January, 1969, we directed the release of these petitioners and said that the reasons would be furnished later.
